qas.question: Who wrote the script for 'Someone's in the Kitchen'?
What video game did Spielberg say in 2013 he's working on a TV show based on?
Who wrote the script for Boombots?
In what year did Boom Blox get released on the Wii?
In what year did The Dig get released?
In what year did the first EA Medal of Honor game get released?
Who is one of the writers for the upcoming Halo tv show?

context: Apart from being an ardent gamer Spielberg has had a long history of involvement in video games. He has been giving thanks to his games of his division DreamWorks Interactive most notable as Someone's in the Kitchen with script written by Animaniacs' <a0_0><b5_0><b9_0>Paul Rugg<b9_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>, Goosebumps: Escape from HorrorLand, The Neverhood (all in <a3_0>1996<a3_0/>), Skullmonkeys, Dilbert's Desktop Games, Goosebumps: Attack of the Mutant (all <a1_0>1997<a1_0/>), Boombots (<a2_0>1999<a2_0/>), T'ai Fu: Wrath of the Tiger (1999), and Clive Barker's Undying (2001). In <b6_0><b7_0>2005<b7_0/><b6_0/> the director signed with Electronic Arts to collaborate on three games including an action game and an award winning puzzle game for the Wii called Boom Blox (and its <b8_0>2009<b8_0/> sequel: Boom Blox Bash Party). Previously, he was involved in creating the scenario for the adventure game The Dig. In 1996, Spielberg worked on and shot original footage for a movie-making simulation game called Steven Spielberg's Director's Chair. He is the creator of the Medal of Honor series by Electronic Arts. He is credited in the special thanks section of the 1998 video game Trespasser. In 2013, Spielberg has announced he is collaborating with 343 Industries for a live-action TV show of <a4_0>Halo<a4_0/>.
